name: E.ON Climate & Renewables North America Reviews

review.title: “E.ON provided a great environment for professional growth and knowledge in the renewable energy industry.”
review.pros: Pros – The people within E.ON all share a common goal of success through a combination of cross-department collaboration and limited supervision. I was able to develop and administrate my department through my own decisions with little involvement from my superiors.
review.cons: Cons – Communication from supervisors and approval from the executive side can prove to be difficult at times, and this issue proved to be a fatal flaw in some activities.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Define the roles of your subordinates, maintain communication with them, and listen to their needs for mutual success.

review.title: “I was proud of the positive environmental work we did.”
review.pros: Pros – E.On Climate & Renewables, formerly known as Airtricity, was an Irish-based company until it was purchased by German-owned E.On. Airtricity was an incredible place to work. A place where I was thoroughly satisfied with my work product and company management. I was proud to work for a wind-farm company and raved about the company to my friends and family. It was a very special group of people doing very rewarding work.
review.cons: Cons – As with many corporate buy-outs, things changed, although not immediately. As time passed, senior management began to leave. New, non-Airtricity folks were hired into senior management roles, and the company lost its synergy. A competitive rift and distrust formed between the Chicago and Austin offices.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Pay attention. Senior and middle-management employees with tenure have left and continue to leave. Ask yourselves why. Stop making excuses. Face the issues. Fix them.

review.title: “Good Place to Work”
review.pros: Pros – Nice people, great company, like it
review.cons: Cons – no room for advancement, or clear career path
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – do more to promote from within
